Whatever we may think oi the extravagant encomiums bestowed upon our author by his chief admirers, and oi the equally extrava- gant abuse to which he has been subjected by his most unreasonable detractors, we must all, I think, recognize in him the sincere patriot, the upright magistrate, and the true man. No more eloquent or earnest advocate ever pleaded the cause of right and of liberty, at the bar or in the Forum. His contributions to letters and to human thought excite our admiration and wonder, alike by their extent and by their excellence. He not only created a language which ior centuries continued to be the language ol scholars throughout the civilized world, buthe alsoen- riched it with those treasures ot literature which have fur- nished models to succeeding generations. Well, then, may we endeavor to estimate at its true value, and with due appreciation‚ the priceless heritage which has come down to us through the centuries from the quiet study of Marcus Cicero.
